title: Derr Run
text:
Derr Run is a <a href="tributary">tributary</a> of <a href="Little%20Muncy%20Creek">Little Muncy Creek</a> in <a href="Lycoming%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lycoming County, Pennsylvania</a>, in the United States. It is approximately long and flows through <a href="Penn%20Township%2C%20Lycoming%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Penn Township</a> and <a href="Franklin%20Township%2C%20Lycoming%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Franklin Township</a>. The watershed of the stream has an area of . It is classified as a Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery.
Course.
Derr Run begins in a small <a href="pond">pond</a> on a hill in Penn Township. It flows south for several tenths of a mile and enters a valley before turning south-southeast. After several tenths of a mile, the stream turns south for a few tenths of a mile before turning south-southeast again and entering Penn Township. Several tenths of a mile further downstream, it turns southeast for several tenths of a mile. The stream then leaves its valley, crosses <a href="Pennsylvania%20Route%20118">Pennsylvania Route 118</a>, and turns southwest, flowing through the valley of Little Muncy Creek. After a few tenths of a mile, it reaches its confluence with Little Muncy Creek.
Derr Run joins Little Muncy Creek upstream of its mouth.
Geography and geology.
The elevation near the <a href="river%20mouth">mouth</a> of Derr Run is above <a href="sea%20level">sea level</a>. The elevation of the stream's <a href="river%20source">source</a> is above sea level.
There is a <a href="spring%20%28hydrology%29">spring</a> in the watershed of Derr Run.
Watershed and biology.
The <a href="drainage%20basin">watershed</a> of Derr Run has an area of . The mouth of the stream is in the <a href="United%20States%20Geological%20Survey">United States Geological Survey</a> quadrangle of Lairdsville. However, its source is in the <a href="quadrangle%20%28geography%29">quadrangle</a> of Picture Rocks. The mouth of the stream is located within of <a href="Lairdsville%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lairdsville</a>.
In 2014, Waste Management of Pennsylvania, Inc. was issued an Erosion and Sediment Control Permit for which the receiving waterbody is Derr Run. In 2007, the US Gypsum Company was issued a permit to build, maintain, and operate a long <a href="natural%20gas">natural gas</a> pipeline crossing the stream in two places, as well as crossing other streams. However, one of the crossings of Derr Run was planned to involve no impact to the stream; the other was planned to impact .
Derr Run is classified as a Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery, as are all of the other named tributaries of Little Muncy Creek.
History.
Derr Run was entered into the <a href="Geographic%20Names%20Information%20System">Geographic Names Information System</a> on August 2, 1979. Its identifier in the Geographic Names Information System is 1192351.
